channel.title: Documentation
channel.generator: Webpage HTML Export plugin for Obsidian

item.title: Apprunner Configurations production and staging
item.description:
Go to AWS Management Console.
Navigate to AppRunner from the AWS Console.


Under Source and Deployment, select Container Registry as the source type.
For more details, refer to the AWS AppRunner Documentation on Source and Deployment








![[Pasted image 20240819124833.png]] Copiar

item.title: Create an RDS Database Instance
item.description:
Start by navigating to the Amazon RDS service in the AWS Management Console to create a new database instance.

Navigate to RDS:
Open the AWS Management Console.
Search for and select "RDS" from the services list.
Create a New Database:
Click on "Create database."
Choose "Standard create."
Select Database Engine:
Choose "PostgreSQL" as the database engine.
Select version "14.6 R1" as the engine version.
Template Selection:
For Production:
Choose the "Production" template.
For Staging:
You may also choose "Production" or another appropriate template based on your staging environment needs.
Availability Configuration:
Set availability to "Single DB Instance."
Database Settings:
Provide a name for your database.
For the password, select "Autogenerate a password" or manually set a strong password.
Instance Configuration:
Choose instance class "Burstable classes (db.t3.micro)" which includes:
2 vCPUs
1 GiB RAM
Network: 2085 Mbps
Storage Configuration:
Adjust storage settings as per your requirements (typically, leave the default settings unless specific needs dictate otherwise).
Enalbed storage autoscaling

Networking Configuration:
Make sure to follow exact same networking config as shown below


Database Authentication:
Choose "Password authentication."
Backup Settings:
Ensure that the "Enable automated backups" option is checked.
Final Review:
Leave all other settings as default unless specific changes are required.
Review your settings and click "Create database" to launch the RDS instance.
item.guid: Developer Documentation/Deployment/Data Base/Amazon Relational Database Service/Create an RDS Database Instance.md

item.title: Import and Export Databases Between RDS Instances
item.description:
Once your RDS instances are set up, you may need to import or export databases between your production and staging environments.

Connect to RDS:
Use a database management tool like pgAdmin or TablePlus.
Connect to your RDS server using the endpoint provided in the RDS console.
Export Database:
From Production or Staging:
Right-click on the database (e.g., staging-db or prod-db).
Select "Backup."
Name the backup file (e.g., prod.sql) and save it locally.
Import Database:
To Production or Staging:
Go to your newly created database instance.
Right-click on the database.
Select "Restore."
Upload the previously saved prod.sql file to start the restoration process.
Verify Database Replication:
After the restore process, your production and staging databases should be replicas of each other.
item.guid: Developer Documentation/Deployment/Data Base/Amazon Relational Database Service/Import and Export Databases Between RDS Instances.md

item.title: Redeploy Application Service
item.description:
After successfully importing the database:

Go to AWS App Runner:
Navigate to the AWS App Runner service in the console.
Deploy the Service:
For Production:
Select the production service (e.g., fm-prod).
Click the "Deploy" button.
For Staging:
Select the staging service (e.g., fm-staging).
Click the "Deploy" button.
Verify Deployment:
Check the application logs and perform a smoke test to confirm that the deployment was successful.
item.guid: Developer Documentation/Deployment/Data Base/Amazon Relational Database Service/Redeploy Application Service.md

item.title: DB update Automation
item.description:
ssh into our EC2 instance named testing jumpbox and run this: 
Copy code sudo systemctl status amazon-ssm-agent 
The above command confirms status of our SSM service 
If it is not installed, you can install it using the package manager for your OS. 


Create an IAM role with the AmazonEC2RoleforSSM managed policy and attach it to your EC2 instance.  
This role is already created and can checked in Roles inside AWS Console 


Create a script on your EC2 instance that will run the required commands (npx prisma db push). For example, create a file /home/ec2-user/update_db.sh with the following content: 
update_db.sh is already been created and will be placed with this document. It contains all the information like .env variables, also pulls latest db updates and run npx prisma db push to update our db 
Ensure the script is executable:
chmod +x /home/ec2-user/update_db.sh 


Created a GitHub Actions workflow that uses the SSM Run Command to execute update_db.sh script on the EC2 instance.(This script is already created and db automation folder.)

item.title: RDS Configuration Guide (Production and Staging)
item.description: This guide provides detailed instructions for configuring Amazon RDS for both production and staging environments, as well as steps for importing and exporting databases between these environments.
item.guid: Developer Documentation/Deployment/Data Base/RDS Configuration Guide (Production and Staging).md

item.title: Update Database via SSM
item.description:
name: Update Database via SSM
on:
push:
branches:
- staging # Trigger the workflow when pushing to staging branch
jobs:
update-database:
runs-on: ubuntu-latest
steps:
- name: Checkout repository
uses: actions/checkout@v2
- name: Update Database Using SSM Run Command
env:
AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: ${{ secrets.AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID_SID }}
AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: ${{ secrets.AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY_SID }}
AWS_DEFAULT_REGION: ${{ secrets.AWS_REGION }}
run: |
aws ssm send-command \ --document-name "AWS-RunShellScript" \ --targets Key=instanceIds,Values=i-04e8455a188ebbd7a \ --parameters commands='["/home/ubuntu/update_db.sh"]' \ --region ${{ secrets.AWS_REGION }} Copiar
item.guid: Developer Documentation/Deployment/Data Base/Update Database via SSM.md

item.title: GEM-System Setup and Deployment Guide (Production and Staging)
item.description:
This guide provides step-by-step instructions for setting up and deploying the GEM-System project locally, and then pushing the Docker image to either the production or staging environments on AWS.

Start by cloning the GEM-System repository from GitHub to your local machine:

Navigate to the GEM-System GitHub repository.
Clone the repository locally using the following command:
git clone https://github.com/Fundminer/GEM-system.git Copiar

To work on the latest codebase, create a new branch from the main branch:

Create a new branch based on main:
git checkout -b your-feature-branch Copiar

Ensure your branch is up-to-date with the latest changes:
git pull origin main` Copiar

Create a .env file in the root directory of your project with the following environment variables. These variables are crucial for configuring your application, authentication, and integration services. Adjust the variables as needed for either production or staging environments.
DATABASE_URL=postgresql://user:password@localhost:5432/mydatabase NEXTAUTH_SECRET=your_nextauth_secret NEXTAUTH_URL=http://localhost:3000 GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=your_google_client_id GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=your_google_client_secret SMTP_USER=your_smtp_user SMTP_PASS=your_smtp_password SMTP_HOST=smtp.yourprovider.com AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=your_aws_access_key_id AWS_ACCESS_KEY_SECRET=your_aws_secret_access_key S3_BUCKET_NAME=your_s3_bucket_name AZURE_AD_CLIENT_ID=your_azure_ad_client_id AZURE_AD_CLIENT_SECRET=your_azure_ad_client_secret AZURE_AD_TENANT_ID=your_azure_ad_tenant_id Copiar

Use Prisma to push the database schema to your PostgreSQL database. This command will update your database to match the Prisma schema:
For more information: see the Prisma DB Push documentation
npx prisma db push Copiar
⚠️ WARNING: currently we use a DB Process Automation

Install all the necessary dependencies for the project using Yarn:
yarn install Copiar

To authenticate with AWS and allow Docker to push images to the Amazon Elastic Container Registry (ECR), use the following general command format. Replace the <aws-region> and <ecr-repo-url> placeholders with the appropriate values for your environment.
aws ecr get-login-password --region <aws-region> | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin <ecr-repo-url> Copiar


Region: us-east-2
ECR Repository URL: 054597337237.dkr.ecr.us-east-2.amazonaws.com


Region: us-east-2
ECR Repository URL: 054597337237.dkr.ecr.us-east-2.amazonaws.com
AWS CLI ECR get-login-password Command

Build a Docker image for your application. The image name should be adjusted according to the environment (production or staging):

For Production
docker build -t fundminer-production .
For Staging
docker build -t fundminer-private .

Tag the Docker image so it can be pushed to the appropriate AWS ECR repository. Use the following commands:
For Production:
docker tag fundminer-production:latest 054597337237.dkr.ecr.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/fundminer-production:latest Copiar
For Staging:
docker tag fundminer-private:latest 054597337237.dkr.ecr.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/fundminer-private:latest` Copiar

Push the Docker image to the AWS ECR repository using the following commands:
For Production:
docker push 054597337237.dkr.ecr.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/fundminer-production:latest Copiar
For Staging:
docker push 054597337237.dkr.ecr.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/fundminer-private:latest Copiar
Review the Docker Push documentation for more details.

It's important to confirm that the Docker image has been successfully pushed to the appropriate repository. You can verify this by checking the timestamp of the image in the repository via the AWS Management Console or CLI.

Once the image is pushed, deploy it to the appropriate App Runner service:

For Production:
Navigate to fm-prod in AWS App Runner.
For Staging:
- Navigate to fm-staging in AWS App Runner.
Click the "Deploy" button for the respective service.
Refer to the AWS App Runner Documentation for more information.
item.guid: Developer Documentation/Deployment/Docker/GEM-System Setup and Deployment Guide (Production and Staging).md

item.title: Retagging Older Docker Images for Rollback
item.description:
This guide explains how to retag an older Docker image in Amazon ECR (Elastic Container Registry) for the purpose of rolling back to a previous version. This can be useful if you need to revert to a known good state in your deployment.

First, you need to pull the existing image from your Amazon ECR repository. This image is identified by its tag or digest (a unique identifier based on the image's content).
Command:
docker pull <your-ecr-repository-uri>:<source-tag> Copiar
Explanation:

<your-ecr-repository-uri>: The URI of your ECR repository.
<source-tag>: The tag or digest of the image you want to pull. In the example, the image is identified by its SHA256 digest.
References:
Amazon ECR Pulling an Image

After pulling the image, the next step is to retag it. Retagging allows you to create a new tag for the same image, which can then be pushed back to the repository under this new tag.
Command:
docker tag <your-ecr-repository-uri>:<source-tag> <your-ecr-repository-uri>:<new-tag> Copiar
Explanation:

<new-tag>: The new tag you want to assign to the image. In the example, latest is used as the new tag, which is commonly used to signify the most recent or preferred version of an image.
References:
Docker Tag

Finally, push the retagged image back to the Amazon ECR repository. This makes the image available under the new tag you assigned.
docker push <your-ecr-repository-uri>:<new-tag> Copiar
Explanation:

Pushing the image with the new tag effectively updates the repository to include this version. If latest is used, this image will now be the default image pulled when no specific tag is provided.
References:
Amazon ECR Pushing an Image
item.guid: Developer Documentation/Deployment/Docker/Retagging Older Docker Images for Rollback.md

item.title: Branch Naming Best Practices
item.description:
Format:
feature/description
bugfix/description
hotfix/description
chore/description
Description: The branch name should clearly describe the task you are working on. This helps other developers quickly understand the purpose of the branch without needing to dive into the code or task details.
Examples:
feature/new-report-functionality
bugfix/fix-login-error
hotfix/urgent-crash-fix
chore/update-dependencies
feature/fme-1182-add-user-profile
Additional Tip: When naming a feature branch, consider including the main function or module it affects, such as feature/user-authentication-upgrade or feature/dashboard-improvements.


Stick to a Naming Convention: Maintain uniformity by adhering to the same naming convention across the entire project or organization. This consistency helps avoid confusion and ensures that all team members are on the same page.
Examples:
If you start using feature/ for new functionalities, make sure every new functionality branch starts with feature/.
Similarly, ensure that bug fixes always start with bugfix/.
Additional Tip: Consistency is key in large projects with multiple contributors. It can help with automating processes, such as CI/CD pipelines that depend on branch names.


Use of Ticket Numbers: When applicable, include the ticket or issue number from your project management tool in the branch name. This practice makes it easier to trace back the branch to its corresponding task or bug report.
Examples:
feature/fme-1182-add-user-profile
bugfix/abc-231-fix-null-pointer-exception
chore/jira-345-update-readme
Additional Tip: Including ticket numbers can be especially useful when reviewing commits or pull requests, as it allows team members to quickly access the related task details.


Preferred Separator: Use hyphens (-) rather than underscores (_) in branch names. Hyphens are generally easier to read and avoid potential issues with certain tools or scripts.
Examples:
feature/new-feature (preferred) vs. feature/new_feature (avoid)
bugfix/fix-crash-on-load vs. bugfix/fix_crash_on_load
Additional Tip: Hyphens are commonly used in URLs and command-line interfaces, making them more versatile and less prone to errors across different systems.


Allowed Characters: Stick to alphanumeric characters and hyphens. Avoid using special characters (e.g., @, !, %, etc.) and spaces in branch names, as these can cause issues with version control systems and other tools.
Examples:
feature/new-user-onboarding (good) vs. feature/new user onboarding (avoid)
hotfix/critical-fix vs. hotfix/critical_fix!
Additional Tip: Keeping branch names simple and free of special characters ensures compatibility across different systems, scripts, and tools used in the development process.
item.guid: Developer Documentation/Version Control Standards/Branches/Branch Naming Best Practices.md

item.title: Commit Message Best Practices
item.description:
Format: Follow the format: [type]: description where the description can be the title of the ticket or a brief summary of the change.
Types: Use the following types to categorize your commits:
feat: For new features.
Example:
feat: Add user authentication
fix: For bug fixes.
Example:
fix: Correct typo in user profile page
docs: For documentation updates.
Example:
docs: Update API usage examples in README
style: For code style changes (formatting, missing semicolons, etc.) that do not affect the functionality.
Example:
style: Reformat code to match style guide
refactor: For code changes that neither fix a bug nor add a feature, but improve code structure or readability.
Example:
refactor: Simplify user input validation logic
test: For adding or updating tests.
Example:
test: Add unit tests for user authentication
chore: For maintenance tasks, such as updating dependencies or configuring build tools.
Example:
chore: Update npm packages to latest versions
Additional Tips:
Ensure your description is specific and concise. It should provide enough context for someone reviewing the commit history to understand the purpose of the change.
If your project management tool assigns ticket numbers, consider including the ticket number in the description.
feat: Add user login functionality (JIRA-123).


Description: Write commit messages in the imperative mood, as if you are commanding the codebase to do something. This approach is widely recommended because it aligns with the way commands are issued to version control systems (e.g., "Git: Apply this change").
Example:
Correct: Add user login functionality
Incorrect: Added user login functionality
Additional Tip: The imperative mood keeps commit messages consistent and actionable. This format is also easier to read in the context of a series of commits, as it reflects the intent behind each change.
item.guid: Developer Documentation/Version Control Standards/Commits/Commit Message Best Practices.md

item.title: Faculty
Award Amount
item.description:
The amount of the award that should be awarded according to the agreement.

My Funds -> Specific Fund -> Account Info -> Criteria & Restrictions ->Award Amount (if default name)

item.title: Purpose
item.description:
The purpose comes directly from the endowment or gift agreement (or amendment) and describes how the funds may be used or may not be used. In the case of a scholarships, the purpose also outlines the student criteria requirements.

My Funds -> Specific Fund -> Account Info -> Criteria & Restrictions -> Purpose (By Default):

item.title: Market Value
item.description:
The market value of a fund is the principal plus any unrealized gains or losses minus distributions, withdrawals, and fees

My Funds -> Specific Fund -> Financial Info -> Investment Account Info -> Market Value.

item.title: YTD Net Distribution
item.description:
The year-to-date net distribution is the portion of the income or return generated by the invested fund that is actually distributed to the spendable operating account.

My Funds -> Specific Fund -> Financial Info -> Investment Account Info -> YTD Net Distribution.
item.guid: Fund/Itemizables/Fields/Common Fields/Investment Account Info/YTD Net Distribution.md

item.title: Ending Balance
item.description:
The spendable operating account Balance

My Funds -> Specific Fund -> Financial Info -> Operating Account Information -> Ending Balance:

item.title: Fund Type
item.description:
Each organization determines the types of funds they offer. Common fund types include, endowment, endowed scholarship, annual scholarship, endowed academic position, and general fund.

My Funds -> Specific Fund -> Account Info -> General Fund Info -> Fund type:

item.title: YTD Expenses
item.description:
Expenditures charged to the operating account in the current fiscal year.

My Funds -> Specific Fund -> Financial Info -> Operation Account Information -> YTD Expenses (if default name)

item.title: Spending Plan Requirement
item.description:
Organizations may require a budget or spending plan from fund managers.

My Funds -> Specific Fund -> Financial Info -> Spending Plan ->Spending Plan Requirement:

item.title: Fields
item.description: Fields could come from different tables and files:

item.title: Invested Fund
item.description:
An endowment fund is a financial asset, typically held by nonprofit organizations, such as universities, hospitals, or foundations, designed to provide long-term financial stability. The principal amount of the fund, which originates from donations, remains invested and is not spent. Instead, the organization only utilizes the income or interest generated from these investments. This ensures that the fund can support the organization's mission indefinitely, as the principal remains intact, allowing it to grow over time.
In essence, the fund is set up to ensure that only the returns on the investment are used for operational expenses, while the original donation stays preserved, enabling a sustainable financial resource for the organization​.

item.title: Not Invested
item.description:
A non-invested fund refers to a fund that is not placed into traditional financial investments like stocks, bonds, or other securities. Instead, the organization manages the funds directly, often using the principal amount for immediate needs or specific projects as outlined by the donor or the organization’s financial strategy.
Unlike an endowment fund, where the principal is typically preserved and only the generated income is used, a non-invested fund might be fully utilized to meet short-term goals or urgent operational requirements. This approach can provide flexibility for the organization to respond to immediate needs, but it does not create a long-term, sustainable income stream.
In essence, a non-invested fund is a financial resource allocated and spent directly, rather than being managed for growth over time through investment.

item.title: Type of Investment
Fund
Compliance Flag Thresholds (required field)
item.description:
Set you customized excess accumulation threshold for
endowed/invested fund. We recommend this threshold to be
set between 1.5-4.0.
The "Compliance Flag Thresholds" section allows you to set a specific numerical value that defines what constitutes "excess accumulation" for an endowed or invested fund. This threshold acts as a trigger point; if the fund's accumulation exceeds this threshold, it will be flagged for potential action, such as increased spending or reinvestment.
If you manage a scholarship fund and set the Compliance Flag Threshold at 2.0, this means the fund is allowed to accumulate up to twice its annual distribution before it is flagged for excess accumulation. If the fund balance exceeds this threshold, the system will alert you, indicating that it might be time to either increase distributions (e.g., offer more scholarships) or reinvest the excess funds in a way that aligns with the fund's objectives.


Excess Accumulation

Set a different Excess Accumulation Threshold per Fund Type
Reconfigure Excess Accumulation variables Pop Up
item.guid: Organization Flags/Flags/Excess Accumulation/Compliance Flag Thresholds (required field).md

item.title: Excess Accumulation
item.description:
Track excess accumulation threshold for endowed/invested funds and tell you which funds need more expenses or reinvestment.
This tracking helps identify whether a fund has accumulated more money than necessary or optimal, potentially indicating that the fund needs to either increase its expenditures or reinvest its excess capital.
Let's say your organization manages a scholarship fund that is supposed to distribute $50,000 annually. If the fund has accumulated $1 million but only disburses $10,000 a year, the excess accumulation might indicate that the fund is not being used as intended.



Compliance Flag Thresholds (required field)



By default, the Excess Accumulation tag triggers based on the following values:

Balance: Ending Balance
Distribution: YTD Net Distribution
You can also configure this in the Compliance Flag Thresholds (required field) section, specifically through the Reconfigure Excess Accumulation variables modal.


Variables for Ratio, balance and distribution may change.


const reconfigureExcessAccumulation = user?.organization.reconfigureExcessAccumulation let distribution = operatingAccount.investments?.at(0)?.investment?.netDistribution let excessBalance = operatingAccount?.cashBalance const threshold =(complianceByType? thresholdByType[fund?.type || ''] : user?.organization.complianceThreshold) || 2 if (fund?.invested === true) { if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('ExcessAccumulation')) { if (reconfigureExcessAccumulation) { distribution = get(fund,user.organization.distributionField || 'investment.netDistribution') if (user.organization.balanceField){ excessBalance = get({...fund,operatingAccount: omit(operatingAccount, ['fund']),},user.organization.balanceField) } if (excessBalance === null) { excessBalance = operatingAccount?.cashBalance } } if (distribution != null && distribution > 0 && excessBalance != null) { if (excessBalance >= threshold * distribution){statusList.push('ExcessAccumulation') } } } Copiar


It will get if Excces Acumulation Variables are changed
It will get Distribution subvariable from Net distribution
It will get ExccesBalance subvariable from CashBalance
It will get Threshold value: Type of Tresholds
If Excess Acumulation Flag is enabled
If Excess Variable is reconfigured (step 1)
Distribution = Selected or Default
Excess Balance = Selected or Default
If Excess Balance >= Threshold * Distribution
Exccess Accumulation Tag Activated.

item.title: Reconfigure Excess Accumulation variables Pop Up
item.description:
"Excess Accumulation variables" refers to the specific financial metrics or data points that are used to calculate or determine the Excess Accumulation Threshold (EAT). These variables are key inputs in the formula or model that assesses whether there is an excess accumulation of resources.
The result of this 2 variables must be a number between 1.5 and 4


Balance:
Ending Balance
Market Value
Distribution:
YTD Net Distribution
Estimated Net Distribution



Compliance Flag Thresholds (required field)
Excess Accumulation
item.guid: Organization Flags/Flags/Excess Accumulation/Reconfigure Excess Accumulation variables Pop Up.md

item.title: Set a different Excess Accumulation Threshold per Fund Type
item.description:
The "Excess Accumulation Threshold" (EAT) refers to a defined limit or threshold above which the accumulation of certain resources or assets is considered excessive or inefficient. This concept can apply in various contexts.



Compliance Flag Thresholds (required field)
Excess Accumulation

List based from Fund Types



It uses the same logic as Excess Accumulation Fund Excess Accumulation Tag.
But the Fund Type will be relevant in order to filter those funds that validate it and those that doesn't.
item.guid: Organization Flags/Flags/Excess Accumulation/Set a different Excess Accumulation Threshold per Fund Type.md

item.title: Negative Balance
item.description:
Reconfigure Negative Balance Variables MODAL

In order for you to achieve compliance for fund, you must contact your system admin to resolve this accounting flag.


Usually by default you can find this trigger value for the Zero Expenditure tag from Ending Balance by default or Reconfigure Negative Balance Variables MODAL if its needed.


///////////// Compliance Status const balance = get(fund,user?.organization.negativeBalanceField || 'operatingAccount.cashBalance') if (balance && balance < 0) { if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('NegativeBalance')) { statusList.push('NegativeBalance') } } ///////////// Compliance const negativeBalance = get(fund,organization.negativeBalanceField || 'operatingAccount.cashBalance') // Ending Balance is Negative if (negativeBalance && negativeBalance < 0) { if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('NegativeBalance')) { // console.log(fund.operatingAccount.code, 'NegativeBalance') statusList.push('NegativeBalance') } } Copiar


Get balance field from Personalized Negative Balance Value or Market Value by default.
if balance is lower than 0
if 1. Organization Negative Balance Option enabled
2. Fund Negative Balance Tag Activated.
Get balance field from Personalized Negative Balance Value or Market Value by default.
if balance is lower than 0
if 1. Organization Negative Balance Option enabled
2. Fund Negative Balance Tag Activated.

item.title: Reconfigure Negative Balance Variables MODAL
item.description:
Ending Balance
Market Value



Negative Balance

List based from Fields
item.guid: Organization Flags/Flags/Negative Balance/Reconfigure Negative Balance Variables MODAL.md

item.title: Reconfigure Zero Expense Variable
item.description:
Specific financial field that is being used to define or track whether an account or fund has incurred any expenses.
The 'expenses' selectable field is for choosing the variable that will represent the expenses flag.
If this variable flag stays 0 it will trigger in the fund the Zero Expenditure flag


YTD Expenses
Award Amount
Estimated Expenses // add in the future



Zero Expenditure

List based from Fields
item.guid: Organization Flags/Flags/Zero Expenditure/Reconfigure Zero Expense Variable.md

item.title: Zero Expenditure
item.description:
Zero Expenditures: Total Capital Out of Compliance
'Track all funds that have $0 in total expenses year-to-date.'

"Zero Expenditure" refers to funds or accounts that have had no expenses recorded year-to-date. This means that throughout the current year, there have been no financial outflows or spending associated with these funds.
Tracking this option makes possible ensuring that the system identifies and monitors any accounts or funds that have not incurred any expenses so far this year. This could be useful for compliance or reporting purposes, where it is important to know which funds have remained untouched in terms of spending.


Reconfigure Zero Expense Variable

Operating fund or account has had no expenses during current fiscal year.


Usually by default you can find this trigger value for the Zero Expenditure tag from YTD Expenses by default or Reconfigure Zero Expense Variable if its already modified.


let expense = get(fund, user?.organization.expensesField || 'operatingAccount.expenses' ) if (!operatingAccount?.encumbrances && expense === 0) { if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('ZeroExpenses')) { statusList.push('ZeroExpenses') } } Copiar


It will get Fund Expense field from either default expenses field that must have YTD Expenses field or it takes a personalized field modified by the Organization Admin. Reconfigure Zero Expense Variable
If
If expenses took from step 1 are equal to 0 it means that this fund have no financial outflows.
if detected and Zero Expenditure flag it's enabled, then add it to the fund Compliance Flags list.

item.title: Amendment In Process
item.description:
Operating fund or account is currently undergoing an amendment to the current fund purpose/criteria.


In order for you to achieve compliance for fund, you must contact your system admin to resolve this amendment flag,

item.title: Holding Account
item.description:
This field defines whether the fund has a holding account or not.


Operating fund or account that is not fully established due to unmet thresholds or other restrictions. Funds on these accounts are usually not deployable.


///////////////// Compliance Status if (fund?.holdingAccount === true) { if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('HoldingAccount')) { statusList.push('HoldingAccount') } } ////////// Compliance if (fund?.holdingAccount === true) { if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('HoldingAccount')) { statusList.push('HoldingAccount') } } Copiar

item.title: Missing Gift Agreement
item.description:
The "Missing Gift Agreement" checks whether any fund has an Agreement Document uploaded in the fund's Documents section.

Using flags like "Missing Gift Agreement" in your fund management system is essential for ensuring that all necessary documentation is in place and up to date, which helps maintain compliance and accountability. These flags act as safeguards by quickly identifying any missing critical documents, allowing your organization to address potential issues proactively. This not only supports transparency and trust with donors but also protects your organization from legal risks and ensures you meet all regulatory requirements. Implementing such compliance measures ultimately helps in building a stronger, more reliable relationship with your donors and stakeholders​.


Documents

Operating fund or account is not currently associated with any gift agreement.



//////////// Compliance Status if (!fund?.documents?.some((document) => document.type?.match(/Agreement/i) !==null)) { if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('MissingGiftAgreement')) { statusList.push('MissingGiftAgreement') } } //////////// Compliance if (!fund?.documents?.some((document) => document.type?.match(/Agreement/i) !==null)) { if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('MissingGiftAgreement')) { statusList.push('MissingGiftAgreement') } } Copiar


if Fund Documents have some Agreement Document Type
if 1. Organization Missing Gift Agreement Option is enabled
2. Fund Missing Gift Agreement Tag Activated.
if Fund Documents have some Agreement Document Type
if 1. Organization Missing Gift Agreement Option is enabled
2. Fund Missing Gift Agreement Tag Activated.

item.title: Needs Review
item.description:
This fund has been flagged by the advancement team as needing a review or needing fund maintenance. Contact your system administrator.
its a manual option for fund tags.

///////////////// Compliance Status if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('NeedsReview')) { statusList.push('NeedsReview') } ////////// Compliance if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('NeedsReview')) { statusList.push('NeedsReview') } Copiar

item.title: Pledge Due
item.description: ///////////////// Compliance Status if (fund?.additional && new Date((fund.additional as any)['pledgeTargetClose']) < new Date()) { statusList.push('PledgeDue') } Copiar

item.title: Spending Plan Pending
item.description:
Track funds on spending plan approval status. Spending plans are usually submitted by the fund manager.
refers to a status or flag indicating that a spending plan has not yet been finalized or submitted for a particular fund or set of funds.

This option allows you to enforce the requirement of having a spending plan only for specific funds, rather than applying this requirement to all funds or all funds of a certain type.
Let's say your organization has several funds, but only Fund 1 and Fund 4 are part of a critical project that requires strict budgeting and oversight. By using this option, you can ensure that only these two funds (Fund 1 and Fund 4) are flagged as "Spending Plan Pending." This way, these funds cannot be used until a detailed spending plan is submitted and approved, ensuring that they are used according to the organization's financial policies.
It can select multiple founds one by one.


If your organization has multiple types of funds, and you only want to enforce the spending plan requirement for "Capital Funds," you would select "Capital Fund" from the dropdown. This means that until a spending plan is in place for each Capital Fund, those funds cannot be used. Other types of funds, such as "Current Use Scholarship," might not require a spending plan if not selected.
Fund Types


Not extra option, all invested founds would need spending plan in order to use the fund.


No extra, all funds would need Spending Plan.


The system administrator has required the submission and approval of a spending plan for this fund. There is no approved spending plan for this fund on file that applies to current fiscal year.

Spending Plan Requirement is the flag field that would trigger the Tag depending on how it was configure in Organization options.


if ( fund?.spendingPlanStatus === 'Required' && allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('SpendingPlanPending') ) { let shouldAddSpendingPlanPending = false switch (spendingPlanOptions?.target) { case 'single': if (spendingPlanOptions?.value?.includes(fund.id)) { shouldAddSpendingPlanPending = true } break case 'type': if (fund.type === spendingPlanOptions?.value) { shouldAddSpendingPlanPending = true } break case 'invested': if (fund.invested === true) { shouldAddSpendingPlanPending = true } break default: shouldAddSpendingPlanPending = true break } if (shouldAddSpendingPlanPending) { statusList.push('SpendingPlanPending') } } Copiar


If Spending Plan Organization Option is selected AND Fund spending plan required
if Required for specific fund selected AND Selected funds include current fund:
Spending Plan Pending Tag Activated
if Require for all funds of a given type selected AND current fund type is one of them:
Spending Plan Pending Tag Activated
if Require for all invested funds selected AND current fund type is one of them:
Spending Plan Pending Tag Activated
if Require for all funds selected
Spending Plan Pending Tag Activated

create a spending plan in order to quit this compliance flag.

item.title: Underwater Endowment
item.description:
Operating fund or account is associated with an investment account that has a market value that is less than either

the amount of the principal gift (book value)
the amount required to be maintained by the donor.



///////////////// Compliance Status if (fund?.investment?.marketValue ?? 0 < 0) { if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('UnderwaterEndowment')) { statusList.push('UnderwaterEndowment') } } ///////////////////// Compliance if (fund?.investment?.marketValue ?? 0 < 0) { if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('UnderwaterEndowment')) { statusList.push('UnderwaterEndowment') } } Copiar


Start
A new CSV file is uploaded.
Check for Column
Does the CSV contain a column named "market value"?
Yes: Continue to Step 3.
No: End process.
Check for Negative Values
Does the "market value" column contain any value equal to -0?
Yes: Proceed to Step 4.
No: End process.
Activate Tag
Activate the [[#2. Found Underwater Endowment Tag]].
End

item.title: Unfilled Faculty Position
item.description:
Operating fund or account currently has an unfilled or unassigned faculty position, where one is available. Only relevant for funds associated to faculty positions.


In order for you to achieve compliance for fund, you must assign an approved faculty or staff to this fund as recipient.


Fund Type



if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('UnfilledFacultyPosition')) { // Check if the fund type contains "Faculty" or "Academic Position" (case-insensitive) if (fund?.type && (/faculty/i.test(fund.type) || /academic position/i.test(fund.type))) { // Check if both faculty name and email are blank const isFacultyNameEmpty = !fund?.faculty?.firstName && !fund?.faculty?.lastName if (isFacultyNameEmpty) { statusList.push('UnfilledFacultyPosition') } } } if (allowedComplianceStatus?.includes('UnfilledFacultyPosition')) { // Check if the fund type contains "Faculty" (case-insensitive) if (fund?.type && /faculty/i.test(fund.type)) { // Check if faculty appointment start date is null if (fund?.faculty?.appointmentStartDate === null) { statusList.push('UnfilledFacultyPosition') } fund?.faculty?.appointmentEndDate // Additional condition: Check if the current date is greater than appointment end date const currentDate = new Date() // Get the current date // Check if appointmentEndDate is defined and not null if (fund?.faculty?.appointmentEndDate) { const appointmentEndDate = new Date(fund.faculty.appointmentEndDate) if (currentDate > appointmentEndDate) { statusList.push('UnfilledFacultyPosition') } } } } Copiar


if Unfilled Faculty Position Flag enabled
If the current fund's Fund Type string contains the word "Faculty"
If Fund's Faculty name is EMPTY and Fund's Faculty last name is EMPTY.
2. Found Unfilled Faculty Position Tag Activated
if Unfilled Faculty Position Flag enabled
If the current fund's Fund Type string contains the word "Faculty"
if Fund's Faculty Appointment Start Date it's null
2. Found Unfilled Faculty Position Tag Activated
if Current Date its newer than Fund's Faculty Appointment End Date
2. Found Unfilled Faculty Position Tag Activated

item.title: Compliance Flags
item.description: Select all compliance flags that you want FundMiner to track based on your organization’s needs
